awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I: Automated Guided Vehicle Wireless Charging Network
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovative Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to increase the uptime of automated guided vehicles (AGVs) and similar robotic systems to nearly one hundred percent at factories and fulfillment centers to further improve productivity and reduce overhead costs. These systems currently experience downtime when they need to be recharged off the assembly, production, or delivery route. The proposed technology develops a distributed wireless charging network that can charge AGVs and similar robotic systems dynamically or while they are in use.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will further the development of switching amplifiers to operate over wide reflected impedance ranges with high intrinsic quality antennas, and the developmet of receiver systems that handle dynamic power ranges. The project will also establish the first distributed network of wireless charging transmitters and nodes programmed and monitored collectively as a single functional unit to maintain the battery capacity of an AGV. The anticipated technical results of this Phase I project are to develop a distributed wireless charging network with multiple transmitters and nodes for AGVs along a test track such that it starts and ends with the same battery capacity after every full lap around the track, verifying the technical viability of the system in the marketplace.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Wireless power systems can improve the productivity of US manufacturing, assembly, and fulfillment processes by wirelessly charging robotic machinery reliably for dynamic load conditions. For this NSF SBIR Phase I project, our objective was to develop a wireless power solution that overcomes the existing challenges with charging robotic vehicles (e.g., automotive guided vehicles or AGVs) at factories and fulfillment centers. 

 

Today, the charging systems for robotic vehicles are primarily contact-based, inductive, and articulating arm systems, which often experience reliability issues when there is even a slight (e.g., less than a centimeter) misalignment between the charging system and the robotic vehicle. If factory or fulfillment workers need to manually plug in the robotic vehicle every day, it essentially defeats the purpose of it being automated. Furthermore, contact-based and articulating arm solutions often experience environmental operational challenges due to issues like dust accumulation and fret corrosion, requiring frequent maintenance and recurrent human interference. Wireless power can be the means of enabling automation at future factories and fulfillment centers by increasing the uptime of these systems and decreasing, or removing altogether, the need of human intervention.

 

The work developed in this Phase I is based on resonant inductive technology. Resonant inductive wireless charging systems use an electromagnetic field to transfer energy between two or more inductively coupled devices. One of the devices is the transmitter (Tx) equipment, such as a charging station, that generates the electromagnetic field used to transmit power. The other device is a receiver (Rx) appliance, such as a robotic vehicle, that receives the electromagnetic energy through resonant inductive coupling. The received electromagnetic energy is converted and conditioned into electrical energy that is used to power the receiver appliance. While this technology has the capability to power devices at significantly further distances (e.g., centimeters apart from one another), it is challenging to implement when distances between the Tx and Rx change significantly (e.g., from millimeters to tens of centimeters). Large changes in distances and load conditions can either lead to complex electronics that result in price-prohibited solutions or are simply not technically feasible with existing topologies.

 

In this NSF SBIR Phase I, we successfully developed a wireless power system that can provide more than 100W while enduring extreme changes in displacement, such as lateral and vertical misalignment between the Tx and Rx. Furthermore, we successfully implemented multiple transmitter systems around a test track, to simulate package pickup and drop off locations, and verified that the robotic vehicle can be powered continuously and maintain the same battery charge level after each lap around the track. 

 

To date, the project has facilitated a commercial development with LGE, Verizon, and Newlab via the 5G Studio Program whereby we demonstrated powering a small robotic vehicle for LGE while communicating via Verizon’s 5G network. We conclusively verified that there were no interference issues operating the wireless communication systems (e.g., 5G communication) while wirelessly powering the robotic vehicle units simultaneously. Furthermore, we are currently negotiating development contracts for these wireless power systems at automotive factories. 


Last Modified: 08/01/2023
Modified by: Josh Yankowitz
